title: Nehemiah Chapter 13 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Nehemiah chapter 13 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Nehemiah Chapter 13 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Nehemiah Chapter 13.

questions.question: According to Nehemiah 13:1, who should not come into the congregation of God forever?
options: The Ammonite and the Moabite
The Philistines
The Egyptians
The Edomites
questions.correctAnswer: The Ammonite and the Moabite
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:1 states that the Ammonite and the Moabite should not come into the congregation of God forever.

questions.question: Why were the Ammonites and Moabites forbidden to join the congregation, according to Nehemiah 13:2?
options: Because they hired Balaam to curse Israel
Because they worshipped idols
Because they destroyed the temple
Because they refused to obey the law
questions.correctAnswer: Because they hired Balaam to curse Israel
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:2 explains that the Ammonites and Moabites hired Balaam to curse Israel, which is why they were excluded.

questions.question: What action was taken when the people heard the law in Nehemiah 13:3?
options: The mixed multitude separated from Israel
The priests offered more sacrifices
The people built new chambers
The Levites sang praises
questions.correctAnswer: The mixed multitude separated from Israel
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:3 states that upon hearing the law, the mixed multitude separated themselves from Israel.

questions.question: Who was allied with Tobiah and prepared a chamber for him in the house of God?
options: Eliashib the priest
Nehemiah
Zadok the scribe
Shelemiah the priest
questions.correctAnswer: Eliashib the priest
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:4 mentions that Eliashib the priest was allied with Tobiah and had prepared a chamber for him.

questions.question: What was stored in the chamber prepared for Tobiah according to Nehemiah 13:5?
options: Meat offerings, frankincense, vessels, tithes of corn, new wine, and oil
Weapons and armor
Scrolls and books
Grain and livestock
questions.correctAnswer: Meat offerings, frankincense, vessels, tithes of corn, new wine, and oil
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:5 describes the chamber as containing offerings and tithes meant for the Levites and priests.

questions.question: Where was Nehemiah during the time Tobiah was given a chamber in the house of God?
options: Not in Jerusalem
In Babylon
In Egypt
In Moab
questions.correctAnswer: Not in Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:6 states that Nehemiah was not in Jerusalem when those events happened.

questions.question: What did Nehemiah do when he discovered the chamber prepared for Tobiah?
options: He cast forth all the household stuff of Tobiah
He joined Tobiah in the chamber
He ignored it
He gave Tobiah more offerings
questions.correctAnswer: He cast forth all the household stuff of Tobiah
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:8 states that Nehemiah was grieved and cast out all of Tobiah’s household stuff from the chamber.

questions.question: What was the reason Levites and singers fled to their fields as mentioned in Nehemiah 13:10?
options: Their portions had not been given to them
A famine had occurred
They were afraid of enemies
They were celebrating a festival
questions.correctAnswer: Their portions had not been given to them
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:10 explains that the Levites fled because their appointed portions had not been provided.

questions.question: Who were appointed as treasurers over the treasuries in Nehemiah 13:13?
options: Shelemiah the priest, Zadok the scribe, and Pedaiah of the Levites
Eliashib, Nehemiah, and Tobiah
Sanballat, Joiada, and Hanan
Balaam, Solomon, and Mattaniah
questions.correctAnswer: Shelemiah the priest, Zadok the scribe, and Pedaiah of the Levites
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:13 names these three as treasurers over the treasuries due to their faithfulness.

questions.question: What did Nehemiah observe happening on the Sabbath in Judah according to Nehemiah 13:15?
options: People treading wine presses and bringing in burdens
Everyone resting and worshipping
Fasting and praying
Building houses
questions.correctAnswer: People treading wine presses and bringing in burdens
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:15 states that people were working on the Sabbath, doing activities like treading wine presses and bringing in loads.

questions.question: True or False: Nehemiah 13:16 states that men of Tyre brought and sold fish and other wares on the Sabbath in Jerusalem.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:16 specifically mentions men of Tyre selling fish and wares on the Sabbath in Jerusalem.

questions.question: True or False: Nehemiah 13:19 records that Nehemiah commanded the gates of Jerusalem to be opened on the Sabbath.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:19 says the gates were shut before the Sabbath and not opened until after the Sabbath.

questions.question: True or False: According to Nehemiah 13:23, some Jews had married wives from Ashdod, Ammon, and Moab.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:23 clearly notes that some Jews had married women from these regions.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Nehemiah 13:14: 'Remember me, O my God, concerning this, and wipe not out my ______ that I have done for the house of my God.'
options: good deeds
sins
prayers
commands
questions.correctAnswer: good deeds
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:14 asks God to remember his good deeds done for the house of God.

questions.question: Who was one of the sons of Joiada, son of Eliashib the high priest, related to, causing Nehemiah to chase him away?
options: Sanballat the Horonite
Tobiah the Ammonite
Balaam the prophet
Shelemiah the priest
questions.correctAnswer: Sanballat the Horonite
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:28 states that one of Joiada’s sons was son-in-law to Sanballat, leading to his removal.

medium.title: Nehemiah Chapter 13 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Nehemiah Chapter 13 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Nehemiah 13 teach us about obedience to God's Word regarding association with unbelievers?
options: Ammonites and Moabites should not enter the congregation of God
All foreigners are welcomed without restriction
People should ignore laws about association
Only priests have rules about association
questions.correctAnswer: Ammonites and Moabites should not enter the congregation of God
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:1-3 explains that the law forbids Ammonites and Moabites from joining the congregation because of their past actions against Israel. This teaches the importance of adhering to God's commands about association and holiness.

questions.question: What lesson about faithfulness in stewardship and church service can we learn from Nehemiah's actions toward Tobiah's chamber?
options: God's house should be kept pure and dedicated to His service
All chambers are equally useful for any purpose
It is acceptable to mix secular and sacred duties
Leaders should ignore misuse of holy places
questions.correctAnswer: God's house should be kept pure and dedicated to His service
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:4-9 shows Nehemiah's grief and decisive action in removing Tobiah's household items from the chamber meant for offerings, emphasizing the need to guard the sanctity of God's house in our stewardship and service.

questions.question: How does Nehemiah 13 highlight the importance of support for those serving in ministry?
options: Levites and singers must receive their portions so they can serve effectively
Ministers should provide for themselves by farming
Support for ministry workers is optional
Only priests deserve support, not Levites or singers
questions.correctAnswer: Levites and singers must receive their portions so they can serve effectively
questions.explanation: Verses 10-13 reveal that the Levites and singers were neglected and returned to their fields due to lack of support, showing the biblical principle of honoring and providing for those who serve the church.

questions.question: What biblical truth about honoring the Sabbath is taught in Nehemiah 13?
options: The Sabbath should be kept holy by resting and not profaning it through commerce
The Sabbath is a flexible day to do business as usual
Merchants can carry goods into the city on the Sabbath
The Sabbath is only for priests and Levites
questions.correctAnswer: The Sabbath should be kept holy by resting and not profaning it through commerce
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:15-22 shows Nehemiah confronting those who profaned the Sabbath by selling goods and working, stressing the importance of Sabbath observance as a sign of obedience and trust in God.

questions.question: Based on Nehemiah 13, what can we learn about spiritual discipline and prayer in leadership?
options: Nehemiah prayed for God to remember his good deeds and mercy
Leaders should rely solely on human wisdom
Prayer is unnecessary if plans are good
God does not respond to prayers about ministry work
questions.correctAnswer: Nehemiah prayed for God to remember his good deeds and mercy
questions.explanation: In verses 14, 22, and 31, Nehemiah repeatedly asks God to remember his faithfulness and deeds, demonstrating the importance of prayer and dependence on God in leadership and service.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with temptation in marriage and family. What biblical counsel from Nehemiah 13 would you share?
options: Avoid marrying outside the faith to prevent spiritual decline
Intermarriage is encouraged to build peace
Family choices have no spiritual consequences
God accepts all marriages equally regardless of faith
questions.correctAnswer: Avoid marrying outside the faith to prevent spiritual decline
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:23-27 warns against marrying foreign wives who lead their children away from the Jewish language and faith, showing the importance of guarding family purity and spiritual discipline in marriage.

questions.question: What does Nehemiah 13 teach about dealing with sin and restoring holiness in the community?
options: Sin must be confronted and cleansed to restore God's covenant
Ignore sin to maintain peace
Sin is a private matter with no communal consequences
Only God can deal with sin, not leaders
questions.correctAnswer: Sin must be confronted and cleansed to restore God's covenant
questions.explanation: Verses 28-30 show Nehemiah taking strong action against those who defiled the priesthood, emphasizing the need for leaders to confront sin and restore holiness in the community.

questions.question: True or False: Nehemiah allowed Tobiah to keep his chamber in the temple courts because he was allied with the priest Eliashib.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Nehemiah was grieved by this alliance and removed Tobiah's household items from the chamber, as described in Nehemiah 13:4-9, showing that he did not allow Tobiah to keep it.

questions.question: True or False: The merchants and sellers stopped coming to Jerusalem on the Sabbath after Nehemiah warned them.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:20-21 explains that after Nehemiah's warning, the merchants no longer came on the Sabbath, honoring the command to keep the day holy.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Nehemiah appointed _____, Zadok the scribe, and Pedaiah as treasurers over the treasuries to distribute to their brethren.
options: Shelemiah the priest
Eliashib the priest
Sanballat the Horonite
Hanan the son of Zaccur
questions.correctAnswer: Shelemiah the priest
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:13 states that Shelemiah the priest, along with Zadok and Pedaiah, were appointed as treasurers, showing the importance of faithful stewardship and accountability.

questions.question: How does Nehemiah 13 teach us about integrity and work ethic in ministry service?
options: Levites fled to their fields when not supported, showing the need for faithful provision
Workers should abandon duty when tired
Integrity is not important in service
Work should be done only when convenient
questions.correctAnswer: Levites fled to their fields when not supported, showing the need for faithful provision
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:10-11 describes how the Levites left their ministry work because their portions were not given, highlighting the importance of integrity and responsibility in ministry and the community's role to support them.

questions.question: What practical lesson about prayer and dependence on God is modeled by Nehemiah in this chapter?
options: Nehemiah repeatedly asks God to remember his deeds and show mercy
Nehemiah relies only on his own strength
Prayer is only necessary for personal needs
God does not respond to prayers about leadership
questions.correctAnswer: Nehemiah repeatedly asks God to remember his deeds and show mercy
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:14, 22, and 31 show his persistent prayers asking God to remember his faithfulness, teaching us the importance of continual dependence on God in leadership and service.

questions.question: How does Nehemiah 13 illustrate the importance of humility and repentance in leadership?
options: Nehemiah confronts sin and calls for obedience to God's covenant
Leaders should ignore problems to avoid conflict
Pride is necessary for leadership
Repentance is a private matter only
questions.correctAnswer: Nehemiah confronts sin and calls for obedience to God's covenant
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:25-30 shows his strong confrontation against intermarriage and defilement of priesthood, modeling humility and repentance to restore holiness and obedience among the people.

questions.question: What does Nehemiah 13 teach about generosity and stewardship in supporting God's work?
options: Judah brought tithes of corn, wine, and oil to the treasuries for distribution
Tithing is optional and unimportant
Only priests should receive tithes
Tithes should be kept privately
questions.correctAnswer: Judah brought tithes of corn, wine, and oil to the treasuries for distribution
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:12-13 highlights the faithfulness of the people in bringing tithes to support the Levites, singers, and priests, teaching stewardship and generosity in God's work.

questions.question: How does this chapter instruct us about protecting the holiness of God's house in practical church life?
options: Cleansing the chambers and appointing faithful officers is necessary
Any use of temple chambers is acceptable
Neglecting the house of God has no consequences
Leaders should allow personal alliances to dictate temple use
questions.correctAnswer: Cleansing the chambers and appointing faithful officers is necessary
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:8-9 and 29-30 show Nehemiah cleansing the rooms and appointing trustworthy leaders to guard the temple, teaching practical steps to maintain holiness and order in church life.

hard.title: Nehemiah Chapter 13 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Nehemiah Chapter 13.

questions.question: According to Nehemiah 13:1-3, why were the Ammonites and Moabites excluded from the congregation of God, and how does this reflect the covenantal purity emphasized in Deuteronomy?
options: Because they did not provide bread and water to Israel and hired Balaam to curse them
Because they refused to worship the God of Israel openly
Because they lived too far from Jerusalem to participate in the congregation
Because they accepted foreign gods and idols
questions.correctAnswer: Because they did not provide bread and water to Israel and hired Balaam to curse them
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:1-3 explains that the Ammonites and Moabites were excluded for their hostility—specifically, not meeting Israel with bread and water and hiring Balaam to curse them. This aligns with Deuteronomy 23:3-6, emphasizing covenantal purity and separation from those who oppose Israel.

questions.question: What role did Eliashib the priest play in Nehemiah 13:4-5, and how does his alliance with Tobiah contrast with his priestly duties?
options: He allied with Tobiah and allowed him to use a chamber in the temple, neglecting priestly responsibilities
He led the Levites in proper temple service as commanded
He expelled Tobiah from the temple chambers
He rebuilt the temple chambers to honor God
questions.correctAnswer: He allied with Tobiah and allowed him to use a chamber in the temple, neglecting priestly responsibilities
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:4-5 describes Eliashib's improper alliance with Tobiah, giving him a chamber that should have been used for offerings and priestly duties, thus violating his sacred oversight.

questions.question: Nehemiah 13:6-9 narrates Nehemiah's reaction on his return to Jerusalem. What actions did he take regarding Tobiah's chamber and the temple vessels?
options: He expelled Tobiah's household items and restored the vessels and offerings to the temple
He left Tobiah's chamber untouched to avoid conflict
He sold the vessels and offerings to fund the temple restoration
He allied with Tobiah to strengthen political ties
questions.correctAnswer: He expelled Tobiah's household items and restored the vessels and offerings to the temple
questions.explanation: Upon return, Nehemiah was grieved (v7-8), cast out Tobiah's belongings, cleansed the chambers, and reinstated the temple vessels and offerings (v9), reaffirming temple sanctity.

questions.question: How does Nehemiah 13:10-13 highlight the neglect of the Levites, and what administrative steps did Nehemiah implement to rectify this?
options: Levites were not receiving their portions and fled to their fields; Nehemiah appointed treasurers to manage offerings
Levites were overburdened with duties; Nehemiah relieved them of responsibilities
Levites were corrupt; Nehemiah exiled them from Jerusalem
Levites were leading rebellion; Nehemiah imprisoned them
questions.correctAnswer: Levites were not receiving their portions and fled to their fields; Nehemiah appointed treasurers to manage offerings
questions.explanation: Verses 10-13 show the Levites deserted temple service due to lack of provision. Nehemiah confronted rulers and established faithful treasurers to ensure proper distribution.

questions.question: What is the significance of Nehemiah's prayer in Nehemiah 13:14 in the context of his reforms?
options: He asks God to remember his good deeds for the house of God and its offices
He confesses his sins and asks for forgiveness
He prays for the destruction of his enemies
He requests wealth and power for himself
questions.correctAnswer: He asks God to remember his good deeds for the house of God and its offices
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:14 reflects his appeal to God to acknowledge his efforts in restoring temple worship and proper administration, underscoring his dedication.

questions.question: Nehemiah 13:15-22 deals extensively with the observance of the Sabbath. What measures did Nehemiah take to enforce Sabbath rest in Jerusalem?
options: He shut the gates before Sabbath and stationed servants to prevent commerce
He allowed merchants to continue selling but restricted only heavy loads
He ignored Sabbath violations to maintain peace
He taxed merchants selling on the Sabbath
questions.correctAnswer: He shut the gates before Sabbath and stationed servants to prevent commerce
questions.explanation: To uphold the Sabbath, Nehemiah closed Jerusalem's gates before dark, set guards to prevent burden-bearing and commercial activity on the Sabbath (v19-21), reflecting strict Sabbath sanctity.

questions.question: What does Nehemiah 13:23-27 reveal about intermarriage and its consequences among the Jews, and how does Nehemiah's response echo earlier biblical warnings?
options: Jews married foreign women, leading to cultural and religious dilution; Nehemiah opposed this, recalling Solomon's failure
Jews strictly avoided intermarriage; Nehemiah praised this
Intermarriage was encouraged to build alliances; Nehemiah supported it
Nehemiah ignored intermarriage to focus on other issues
questions.correctAnswer: Jews married foreign women, leading to cultural and religious dilution; Nehemiah opposed this, recalling Solomon's failure
questions.explanation: Verses 23-27 describe Jews marrying women from Ashdod, Ammon, and Moab, resulting in children unable to speak Hebrew, highlighting cultural loss. Nehemiah condemns this, referencing Solomon's sin (v26) as a historical precedent.

questions.question: In Nehemiah 13:28-29, what was the significance of Nehemiah expelling the son of Joiada, and what does this indicate about the relationship between the priesthood and foreign alliances?
options: The son of Joiada was son-in-law to Sanballat, a foreign leader, defiling the priesthood; Nehemiah expelled him
The son of Joiada was a faithful servant; Nehemiah promoted him
The son of Joiada led a rebellion; Nehemiah imprisoned him
The son of Joiada was unrelated to foreign alliances; Nehemiah ignored him
questions.correctAnswer: The son of Joiada was son-in-law to Sanballat, a foreign leader, defiling the priesthood; Nehemiah expelled him
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:28-29 shows concern for purity of the priesthood, as foreign ties like marriage to Sanballat's family compromised covenant faithfulness, prompting his expulsion.

questions.question: How does the phrase 'Remember me, O my God' found in Nehemiah 13:14, 22, and 31 function within the literary structure of the chapter?
options: It serves as a repeated plea highlighting Nehemiah's reliance on divine approval for his reforms
It is a common closing phrase in ancient Near Eastern texts without special significance
It is an ironic lament indicating Nehemiah's despair
It is a legal formula to claim property rights
questions.correctAnswer: It serves as a repeated plea highlighting Nehemiah's reliance on divine approval for his reforms
questions.explanation: The repeated use of 'Remember me, O my God' frames the chapter's reform narrative, underscoring Nehemiah's dependence on God's recognition and mercy for success (v14, 22, 31).

questions.question: True or False: Nehemiah 13 indicates that foreign merchants from Tyre sold goods on the Sabbath, which Nehemiah opposed to maintain the sanctity of the day.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:16 records men of Tyre selling fish and wares on the Sabbath, which Nehemiah contested to prevent profaning the sacred day.

questions.question: What is the significance of Nehemiah appointing Shelemiah, Zadok, and Pedaiah as treasurers in Nehemiah 13:13, and how does this reflect the administrative reforms in post-exilic Judah?
options: They were trusted officials to ensure proper distribution of tithes, reflecting renewed temple governance
They were military leaders appointed to guard the city gates
They were foreign officials placed to monitor Judah's affairs
They were prophets sent to warn the people
questions.correctAnswer: They were trusted officials to ensure proper distribution of tithes, reflecting renewed temple governance
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:13 shows administrative restructuring with faithful individuals overseeing temple resources, demonstrating efforts to restore proper religious order after exile.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Nehemiah 13:24 highlights that the children of Jews who married foreign wives could not speak the ______ language but spoke the language of their mothers' peoples.
options: Jewish
Aramaic
Greek
Egyptian
questions.correctAnswer: Jewish
questions.explanation: Verse 24 specifically says the children 'could not speak in the Jews' language' but spoke the language of Ashdod and other peoples.

questions.question: What historical figure does Nehemiah reference in Nehemiah 13:26 to illustrate the dangers of marrying foreign women, and what is the theological implication of this reference?
options: Solomon, showing that even the wisest king was led to sin by foreign wives
David, who united the tribes of Israel
Moses, who led Israel out of Egypt
Nebuchadnezzar, the Babylonian king
questions.correctAnswer: Solomon, showing that even the wisest king was led to sin by foreign wives
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:26 recalls Solomon's sin due to foreign wives, emphasizing the recurring theme of faithfulness versus apostasy in Israel's history.

questions.question: In Nehemiah 13:19-21, what was the practical effect of closing Jerusalem's gates before the Sabbath, and how does this relate to ancient Near Eastern urban practices?
options: It prevented goods from being brought into the city, ensuring Sabbath rest and reflecting gate control customs for security and religious observance
It was a symbolic gesture with no real enforcement
It allowed merchants to continue trading within the city
It was done to prevent enemy invasion
questions.correctAnswer: It prevented goods from being brought into the city, ensuring Sabbath rest and reflecting gate control customs for security and religious observance
questions.explanation: Closing gates regulated commerce and movement, a common practice in ancient cities for both security and religious observance, here used to enforce Sabbath sanctity (v19-21).

questions.question: How does Nehemiah 13:30-31 conclude the chapter's narrative, and what themes does this conclusion emphasize for the post-exilic community?
options: Cleansing from strangers and appointing priests and Levites in their duties, with a plea for divine remembrance highlighting restoration and covenant fidelity
A call for military conquest against enemies
A warning of impending exile due to disobedience
Instructions to build a new temple
questions.correctAnswer: Cleansing from strangers and appointing priests and Levites in their duties, with a plea for divine remembrance highlighting restoration and covenant fidelity
questions.explanation: The chapter ends with purification and proper appointment of temple workers, reflecting themes of holiness, restoration, and dependence on God's mercy (v30-31).

theological.title: Nehemiah Chapter 13 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Nehemiah Chapter 13 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Nehemiah 13:1-3, why were the Ammonites and Moabites excluded from the congregation of God?
options: Because they did not provide bread and water to Israel and hired Balaam to curse them
Because they worshipped foreign gods openly in the temple
Because they refused to pay tithes to the Levites
Because they were descendants of Cain
questions.correctAnswer: Because they did not provide bread and water to Israel and hired Balaam to curse them
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:1-3 states the reason for exclusion is their failure to support Israel and their hiring of Balaam to curse Israel, which God turned into a blessing. This reflects God's holiness and the importance of covenant faithfulness (Deuteronomy 23:3-6; Numbers 22-24; Romans 11:29; Hebrews 12:14).

questions.question: What action did Nehemiah take when he discovered Eliashib the priest had allied with Tobiah and given him a chamber in the temple courts?
options: He threw out Tobiah's household goods and restored the temple chambers
He prayed silently and left the city
He sent a delegation to negotiate with Tobiah
He made Tobiah a high priest
questions.correctAnswer: He threw out Tobiah's household goods and restored the temple chambers
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:7-9 recounts how Nehemiah was grieved, cast out Tobiah's belongings, and cleansed the chambers to restore proper worship, demonstrating zeal for God's holiness (Exodus 30:1-10; Malachi 3:1-4; John 2:13-17; Hebrews 10:25).

questions.question: Why had the Levites and singers fled every one to his field, according to Nehemiah 13:10-11?
options: Because their portions and tithes had not been given to them
Because they were afraid of Tobiah
Because the temple gates were closed
Because they were punished for profaning the Sabbath
questions.correctAnswer: Because their portions and tithes had not been given to them
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:10-11 shows that withholding support from the Levites led to their desertion, violating God's provision for temple workers (Leviticus 27:30-33; Numbers 18:21-24; Malachi 3:8-10; 1 Corinthians 9:13-14).

questions.question: How did Nehemiah ensure the proper distribution of tithes and offerings after his return to Jerusalem?
options: He appointed treasurers who were faithful to oversee the distribution
He personally distributed all the offerings
He gave the offerings to the nobles of Judah
He sent the offerings back to Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: He appointed treasurers who were faithful to oversee the distribution
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:12-13 recounts that treasurers Shelemiah, Zadok, and Pedaiah were appointed to oversee distribution, ensuring faithfulness in stewardship, consistent with biblical principles of orderly worship and accountability (2 Chronicles 31:11-12; 1 Corinthians 4:2; Hebrews 7:2-3; Luke 12:42-44).

questions.question: What was Nehemiah's response to people treading winepresses and bringing burdens into Jerusalem on the Sabbath (Nehemiah 13:15-18)?
options: He contended with the nobles and rebuked them for profaning the Sabbath
He allowed it because it was necessary for survival
He ignored it to avoid conflict
He joined them in their activities
questions.correctAnswer: He contended with the nobles and rebuked them for profaning the Sabbath
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:15-18 shows his zealous defense of the Sabbath as holy, rebuking those who profaned it, reflecting God's command to keep the Sabbath holy (Exodus 20:8-11; Isaiah 56:2-7; Luke 6:6-11; Hebrews 4:9-11).

questions.question: How did Nehemiah enforce Sabbath observance in Jerusalem regarding the city gates?
options: He commanded the gates to be shut before the Sabbath and guarded to prevent burdens entering
He left the gates open for merchants
He built new gates for Sabbath traffic
He allowed gates to be open only during the day
questions.correctAnswer: He commanded the gates to be shut before the Sabbath and guarded to prevent burdens entering
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:19-21 describes his command to close the gates and station servants to guard them, preventing commerce on the Sabbath, enforcing holiness and rest (Exodus 16:23-30; Nehemiah 10:31; Jeremiah 17:21-27; Luke 4:16).

questions.question: What problem did Nehemiah observe concerning the intermarriage of Jews with foreign women (Nehemiah 13:23-27)?
options: Their children could not speak the Jewish language and this led to spiritual defection
Their wives were from the tribe of Levi
They all converted to Judaism
They were celebrated as a sign of unity
questions.correctAnswer: Their children could not speak the Jewish language and this led to spiritual defection
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:23-27 highlights the linguistic and spiritual problems from intermarriage with Ashdod, Ammon, and Moab, threatening covenant identity, reflecting God's call for holiness and separation (Deuteronomy 7:3-4; Ezra 9:1-2; Malachi 2:11-12; 2 Corinthians 6:14-18).

questions.question: Which king is referenced by Nehemiah as an example of sin caused by marrying foreign wives, yet loved by God (Nehemiah 13:26)?
options: Solomon
David
Hezekiah
Josiah
questions.correctAnswer: Solomon
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:26 refers to Solomon's sin with foreign women causing idolatry, yet God loved him and made him king, illustrating God's grace despite human failure (1 Kings 11:1-13; Psalm 89:20-37; James 2:10; Romans 5:20).

questions.question: What action did Nehemiah take regarding the son of Joiada who was son-in-law to Sanballat the Horonite (Nehemiah 13:28)?
options: He chased him away
He promoted him to a priestly office
He married his daughter to him
He ignored the relationship
questions.correctAnswer: He chased him away
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:28 shows Nehemiah's decisive action to remove those who defiled the priesthood through ungodly alliances, emphasizing the importance of purity in God's covenant community (Exodus 19:5-6; Malachi 2:8-9; 2 Corinthians 6:14-18; Titus 1:5-9).

questions.question: What does Nehemiah repeatedly ask God to do in verses 14, 22, and 31 of this chapter?
options: Remember him and not wipe out his good deeds
Send an angel to punish the wicked
Deliver him from his enemies
Grant him great riches
questions.correctAnswer: Remember him and not wipe out his good deeds
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:14,22,31 reveal his prayer for God to remember his faithful service, consistent with biblical teaching on divine remembrance of righteous acts (Psalm 103:2; Isaiah 49:15-16; Revelation 20:12; Hebrews 6:10).

questions.question: What theological principle about God's covenant is illustrated by Nehemiah cleansing the temple from Tobiah's household goods (Nehemiah 13:8-9)?
options: God's holiness demands separation from defilement
God accepts all sacrifices regardless of impurity
The temple can be shared with foreign allies
Human alliances override divine commands
questions.correctAnswer: God's holiness demands separation from defilement
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:8-9 reflects God's demand for holiness and purity in His dwelling place, consistent with Levitical laws and New Testament teaching on the church as God's temple (Leviticus 19:2; 1 Corinthians 3:16-17; 2 Corinthians 6:16; Hebrews 12:14).

questions.question: How does Nehemiah 13 demonstrate the doctrine of human responsibility in covenant faithfulness?
options: By showing Nehemiah's active reform and enforcement of God's law
By suggesting that human effort is unnecessary
By emphasizing predestination over obedience
By denying the need for temple worship
questions.correctAnswer: By showing Nehemiah's active reform and enforcement of God's law
questions.explanation: Throughout the chapter, Nehemiah's leadership and enforcement of covenant laws illustrate human responsibility in obedience and holiness (Deuteronomy 30:15-20; Joshua 24:15; Ezekiel 18:20-24; Philippians 2:12-13).

questions.question: What does Nehemiah’s opposition to commerce on the Sabbath imply about the nature of Sabbath observance (Nehemiah 13:15-22)?
options: Sabbath is a sacred time set apart from ordinary labor and commerce
Sabbath is optional and can be broken for business
Sabbath is only a cultural tradition
Sabbath was abolished in Nehemiah's time
questions.correctAnswer: Sabbath is a sacred time set apart from ordinary labor and commerce
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:15-22 shows strict enforcement of Sabbath rest, aligning with Exodus 20:8-11, Isaiah 58:13-14, and Mark 2:27, affirming Sabbath as holy and for rest and worship.

questions.question: What ecclesiological principle is exemplified by Nehemiah's appointment of treasurers and ordering Levites to keep the gates (Nehemiah 13:13,22)?
options: Orderly stewardship and sanctification of worship
Democratic voting for church leaders
Disregard for temple roles
Individualistic worship without leadership
questions.correctAnswer: Orderly stewardship and sanctification of worship
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:13,22 demonstrates organized leadership and roles in worship, reflecting biblical principles of church order (1 Corinthians 12:28; Titus 1:5; Hebrews 13:17; 1 Timothy 3:1-13).

questions.question: How does Nehemiah 13 portray the relationship between sin and communal consequences?
options: Sin leads to divine wrath affecting the entire community
Sin only affects the individual sinner
Sin is overlooked by God in communal life
Sin has no real consequences in society
questions.correctAnswer: Sin leads to divine wrath affecting the entire community
questions.explanation: Nehemiah 13:18 references past wrath brought by disobedience, teaching that sin incurs collective consequences, consistent with passages like Exodus 32:25-35, 2 Chronicles 7:13-14, Romans 1:18-32, and 1 Corinthians 5:1-5.
